items.editorNote: Chainalysis reports that in 2025, stablecoins accounted for 84% of $154 billion illicit crypto volume, overtaking Bitcoin as the primary dark web crime currency.
keyPoints: Bitcoin's share of illicit crypto transactions fell sharply from 97% in 2016 to under 20% in 2022, continuing to decline through 2025.
The rise of stablecoins enables scalable money laundering operations by Chinese networks and sanctions evasion by North Korea, Russia, and Iran.
Illicit stablecoin transactions reached $154 billion in 2025, reflecting a shift toward dollar-pegged programmable currencies in the underground economy.
This trend signals a systemic risk as programmable dollar assets become the dominant medium for illicit finance, challenging regulatory controls.

readOriginal.reason: The original article includes a detailed Chainalysis illicit activity chart from 2020–2025 and contextual analysis of nation-state involvement and laundering-as-a-service trends.
readOriginal.whoShouldRead: Crypto compliance officers, financial crime analysts, and policymakers monitoring illicit finance and cryptocurrency regulation.

items.originalTitle: Stablecoins just replaced Bitcoin for crime on the dark web – and the reason why is a $154 billion nightmare
